Title.evidence: The Effect of Popliteus Tendon Resection on Knee Stability in Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to two groups

Participants.evidence: 18 patients scheduled for posterior stabilized TKA, conducted at a single surgical center

Intervention.evidence: Group A (n=9) underwent popliteus tendon resection, while Group B (n=9) did not

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the impact of popliteus tendon resection on knee ligament balancing and load distribution during TKA

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was knee stability, assessed intraoperatively by a blinded senior surgeon

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: assessed intraoperatively by a blinded senior surgeon

Number_Randomised.evidence: Group A (n=9) underwent popliteus tendon resection, while Group B (n=9) did not

Result_Outcome.evidence: The senior surgeon detected no difference in knee stability between the groups

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group
